verses.text: My son, pay attention to what I say; listen closely to my words.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4
rsbNotes.text:
4:1–27 This chapter most naturally divides into three instructional sayings, each beginning with the usual address of father to son (vv. 1, 10, 20). The first saying sees wisdom as a most precious acquisition (vv. 1–9), the second as the path to true life (vv. 10–19), and the third as the way of uprightness (vv. 20–27). There is no direct reference to religion.

Wisdom traditions are shared by peoples of different cultures and religions. See notes 22:17–24:22. Solomon discussed wisdom with people from other nations (1 Kin. 4:29–34; 10:1–7), showing how certain features of wisdom were shared across national and religious boundaries. In Israel, the insights of empirical wisdom were used in the framework of the covenant relationship and cannot be separated from special revelation (1:7 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4:20–27
rsbNotes.text: 4:20–27 This instruction contrasts the two ways of wisdom and folly without using those terms. The emphasis is on concentration of mind and attention to the wisdom teaching, which leads to life.

verses.text: Do not let them out of your sight, keep them within your heart;

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4:21
rsbNotes.text: 4:21 heart. Or, the mind (2:2 note).

verses.text: for they are life to those who find them and health to a man's whole body.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4:22
rsbNotes.text: 4:22 healing. Wholeness and soundness that includes the body (3:8).

verses.text: Above all else, guard your heart, for it is the wellspring of life.
Put away perversity from your mouth; keep corrupt talk far from your lips.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4:23
rsbNotes.text: 4:23 from it . . . life. Our thoughts in turn shape the way we speak and live. See Matt. 12:35; Mark 7:21; Rom. 2:29.

verses.text: Let your eyes look straight ahead, fix your gaze directly before you.
Make level paths for your feet and take only ways that are firm.
Do not swerve to the right or the left; keep your foot from evil.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 4:25–27
rsbNotes.text: 4:25–27 Wisdom enables one to keep to life’s path without swerving into the mire.
